36.title: Constipation
dlg:
Note that:

  1. Stool that is black may mean that the blood is coming from the upper part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract (esophagus, stomach, and the first part of the small intestine).
  2. Bright red blood or maroon-colored stools may mean that the blood is coming from the lower part of the GI tract (large bowel, rectum, or anus).

Blood will usually look black like tar after it has passed through the intestines because it has been exposed to the body's digestive juices.

0.header:
You would consider yourself constipated if you have most of the symptoms listed below.

 

  • Have a bowel movement of less than 3 times a week.

  • Have hard stools.

  • Have difficulty passing stools.

  • Have pain while passing stools.

  • Unable to pass stool after pushing for more than 10 minutes.

  • Have a sense of incomplete evacuation after stooling.



Let's take a look at what is going on.

1.header: Did the constipation start suddenly and you also have abdominal pain?

3.header: Did it start suddenly and you also cannot pass gas or any stool?

4.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • Looking at something serious.
  • Do not take any laxative until you see a doctor.

5.header:
Is there blood coming out when you try to empty your bowel

Or in the stool?

6.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • Need to rule out other causes which could be serious.
  • Even if you think it is hemorrhoids, you still need to see your doctor.

7.header:
With this constipation, are you experiencing nausea and/or vomiting?

Feeling bloated?

8.header:
Seek urgent care or call the doctor.

Here is why:

  • This may suggest serious obstruction.

Require examination and tests by the doctor such as:

  • Flat and upright abdominal x-rays
  • Water-soluble contrast enema to evaluate for colonic obstruction.
  • Barium x-ray of the small intestine
  • Possibly a CT scan
  • Sigmoidoscopy or
  • Colonoscopy.

9.header:
Are you having sharp stomach pains with this constipation?

Or a tense stomach?

10.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • This may suggest mechanical obstruction.

11.header: Is this constipation alternating with watery diarrhea?

12.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • You may be looking at fecal impaction here. This is serious.
  • May also be looking at Irritable bowel syndrome

Call now if the diarrhea contains:

  • Watery mucus
  • particles of feces
  • and you have stomach cramps.

13.header: What about thin, pencil-like stools in addition to feeling constipated?

14.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • Possible bowel obstruction
  • Fecal impaction

15.header:
Have you lost weight that you didn't want to lose lately

in addition to this constipation?

16.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • Need complete evaluation.

17.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • Need complete evaluation.

20.header: Do you delay going to the bathroom when you have the urge to go?

21.header:
Yes?
You will have to stop this. This is a major cause of constipation.

This is one reason travellers always have constipation. Aside from having to sit in one place for a long time leading to lack of physical activity.

22.header: What about your diet? Is it low in fiber?

23.header:
Yes?
You will have to stop this. This is a major cause of constipation.

This is one reason travellers always have constipation. Aside from having to sit in one place for a long time leading to lack of physical activity.

24.header: What about your diet? Is it low in fiber?

26.header:
Are you currently taking any of the groups of medications listed below?

Medications that are:

  • Antihistamines
  • Antispasmodics
  • Antiparkinsonian drugs
  • Ca channel blockers
  • Opioid pain relievers
  • Antipsychotics
  • Iron, aluminum, Calcium, Bismuth?

27.header:
Yes?
These can cause constipation.

If you just started taking the medications, discuss this with your doctor.

If you are taking iron suplements, switch to the ones that will cause less constipation. The pharmacist may discuss this with you later.

28.header:
There are other causes of constipation that we did not mention.

Top among them is stress.

Let's continue and see what a pharmacist recommend over the counter to help with the constipation.

30.header: How many days has it been since your last bowel movement?

31.header:
You said:{{currentTemp}}day(s)

Option1

32.header:
You said:{{currentTemp}}day(s)

Option2

33.header:
You said:{{currentTemp}}day(s)

Option3

37.title: Diarrhea
dlg:
The most common cause is a viral infection of the digestive track. Bacteria and parasites can also cause diarrhea and this can be very contagious. This will usually be preceded by nausea and vomiting.

Diarrhea of any duration may cause dehydration, which means the body lacks enough fluid and electrolytes to function properly.

0.header:
You must be passing loose stools 3 or more times a day.

This can go away on its own or be a sign of a serious problem or lead to dehydration.



Before we continue, let's make sure you are not looking at a medical emergency.

1.header: In addition to this diarrhea are you also feeling faint or dizzy?

2.header:
Yes?
You have to watch out for dehydration which can be dangerous.

3.header: Are you getting more confused with things around you?

4.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room visit.

Here is why:

  • You may be facing severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalance
  • If you are too weak, go to the nearest emergency room now.

5.header: Is your mouth feeling dry or sticky?

6.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room visit.

Here is why:

  • You may be looking at severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
  • If you are feeling very weak, go to the nearest emergency room now

7.header: Do you feel you are breathing abnormally?

8.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room.

Here is why:

  • Sign of dehydration

9.header: Would you say your heart rate has increased dramatically since this diarrhea?

10.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room.

Here is why:

  • Sign of dehydration

11.header: Are your eyes looking blood shot?

12.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room.

Here is why:

  • Possibly suffering from severe dehydration
  • Possibly suffering from electrolyte imbalance.

13.header:
Has it been more than 8 hours since the diarrhea started..

..and you have not had a urine output?

14.header:
Seek urgent care or call the doctor.

Here is why:

  • Sign of a possible dehydration.

15.header:
Gently pinch and release your skin in the stomach area.

Did it flatten back to normal right away?

16.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room visit.

Here is why:

  • Possibly getting dehydrated.
  • When dehydrated, the skin does not flatten back to normal right away after being gently pinched and released.

17.header:
You just went through signs of a posssible dehydration.

If you were told to seek urgent care or emergency room visit, please do.

Dehydration can quickly result in coma, organ damage and ultimately death.

If this is not the case with you, let's take a look at the nature of the diarrhea and determine if you can ride it out or need to see a doctor as soon as possible.

20.header: Any blood in the watery stool?

21.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room.

Here is why:

  • Possible bacteria or parasites invading your bowels.
  • Tests to determine the cause of the blood in the stool is required.
  • Maroon-colored or bright red blood often mean that the blood is coming from the small or large intestine, rectum, or anal area.
  • If this keeps happening you may be looking at an inflammatory bowel disease.

22.header: Do you also have a fever above 101°F with this diarrhea?

23.header:
Seek urgent care or call the doctor.

Here is why:

  • Possible bacteria, viral or parasite invasion.

24.header:
Is it watery, oily and you also have stomach cramps?

Including gas?

25.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • You may have bacteria or parasite related diarrhea.
  • Need antibiotics for bacteria or parasite related diarrhea.
  • OTC antidiarrhea medications may prolong the problem.

Meanwhile, drink a lot of fluids to prevent dehydration and stay away from caffeine.

26.header:
Do you have middle abdominal pain, back pain with this diarrhea?

And a high fever?

27.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • Symptoms of gallbladder disease
  • Symptoms of pancreatitis

28.header:
Are you experiencing severe lower abdominal pain, cramping with this diarrhea?

And feeling bloated?

29.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room visit.

Here is why:

  • May be looking at intestinal blockage.
  • Consider this an emergency especially if the pain is severe.

30.header:
What about stomach pain or cramps...

...And you also have blood and/or mucus in the stool?

31.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • Your bowels may be inflammed.
  • Possibly looking at inflammatory bowel disease or Crohn's disease.

32.header: Were you constipated before and all of a sudden you are having watery diarrhea?

33.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • You may be looking at fecal impaction.
  • There may be a large mass of dry hard stool trapped in the rectum.

34.header: Did you travel overseas lately?

35.header:
Seek urgent care or call your doctor.

Here is why:

  • You may have traveler's diarrhea caused by contaminated food or drink.
  • You will need antibiotics to deal with this.

36.header:
The nature of the diarrhea can help you make a good decision on what to do.

Let's see what we can come up with.

40.header:
Did the diarrhea start after you ate dairy products like ice cream, yogurt, cream cheese?

Or drank some milk?
Assuming they were in good condition.

41.header:
Yes?
The diarrhea may be due to lactose intolerance.

In this case, you are having problems digesting lactose (sugar found in milk products).

Know that certain types of sugar substitutes in excessive quantities can also cause diarrhea.

42.header:
Is the diarrhea watery and you have a low grade fever?

Including body ache, headache?

43.header:
Yes?
You may be looking at a stomach flu situation.

You need to prevent dehydration by drinking lots of fluid. Get plenty of rest.

If the fever is very high or the symptoms last for more than 10 days, then you will have to see a doctor.

Would you like to see the entry for stomach flu or Continue?

44.header:
Is the volume of the diarrhea large?

Very watery or fatty?
And you know it is not what you ate.

45.header:
Yes?
The problem is most likely with the small intestine.

If it continues for more than 2 days, you will have to see a doctor for this.

It could be due to your gall bladder, nerves, something speeding up movement of the intestines or even has to do with your throid hormones.

46.header:
Is this more like small but frequent stools?

Mostly with abdominal pain?

47.header:
Yes?
The problem is likely with the colons or large intestine.

If you don't know what is causing this, give the doctor a call. You may need to do colonoscopy.

Another possible cause is IBS (Irritable bowel syndrome). With IBS, the abdominal pain will be relieved after using the bathroom.

48.header:
Are you currently taking any of the medications listed below?

Such as:

  • Laxatives
  • Magnesium containing antacids
  • Antibiotics
  • Colchicine
  • Quinine/quinidine
  • Caffeine
  • Antineoplastic drugs
  • Elixirs with lactose in them.
  • SSRIs
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors (Aricept, Exelon, Razadyne, Cognex)

49.header:
Yes?
These can cause diarrhea. Discuss this with the doctor if it is severe.

50.header: Have you taken any antibiotic within the past 2 months?

51.header:
Yes?
Antibiotics can cause diarrhea even up to 2 months later.

They kill both the good and bad bacteria in the intestines. If the good ones are not replaced on time while the bad ones grew faster, this can lead to diarrhea.

Also diarrhea causing bacteria such as Clostridium difficile can grow after the use of antibiotics.

52.header:
Alright.
The goal with diarrhea is to prevent dehydration and electrolyte loss.

Signs of dehydration include:

  • Dark colored urine
  • Thirst
  • Dry or sticky mouth
  • Dry skin
  • Feeling dizzy or lightheaded
  • Low or no urine output
  • Sunken eyes

Let's see what a pharmacist recommend for diarrhea that is available over the counter.

But before that just one more question.

60.header: How many times have you been to the bathroom since it all started?

61.header:
You said:{{currentTemp}} times

Not too bad so far.

If you don't think you need to seek urgent care from the discussions so far, the goal will be to prevent dehydration.

Let's see what a pharmacist recommend for this or would you like to see the nearest urgent care clinic to you?

62.header:
You said:{{currentTemp}} times

Getting bad?

If you don't think you need to seek urgent care from the discussions so far, the goal will be to prevent dehydration and let it run its course.

Let's see what a pharmacist recommend for this or would you like to see the nearest urgent care clinic to you?

63.header:
You said:{{currentTemp}} times

Bad?

If you don't think you need to seek urgent care from the discussions so far, the goal will be to prevent dehydration and let it run its course.

If you think you are dehydrated, seek urgent care.

If for some reason you cannot seek urgent care, let's see what a pharmacist recommend over the counter to help prevent further dehydration.

0.header:
Let's see what to use for nausea and or vomiting over-the-counter.

Many things can cause nausea. Viral infection such as stomach flu, gallstones, motion sickness, pregnancy or even fear and anxiety to name a few.



Let's determine the best course of action to take with this nausea and vomiting.

1.header: With this nausea and or vomiting do you have any fever (may be low-grade) and or chills?

2.header:
Nausea with fever, may indicate something serious going on.

Let's navigate this carefully and decide if you need to seek urgent care or if you can ride this out.

4.header: In addition to this nausea and fever, do you also have diarrhea?

5.header:
Yes?
May be looking at the stomach flu or food poisoning.

Let's see if that is what you are probably looking at.

6.header:
Anybody else with the same symptoms, but you did not eat the same food?

In other words do you know if there is a bug going around?

7.header:
Yes?
Probably looking at stomach flu. (viral gastroenteritis)

Stomach flu starts when you:

  • come in contact with an infected person,
  • were exposed to an infected person through poor sanitation
  • or you ate or drank a contaminated food or water.

Would you like to see the entry for stomach flu or Continue?

8.header: Anybody else has the same symptoms and you ate the same food?

9.header:
Yes?
Probably looking at food poisoning.

Suspect food poisoning if someone else is sick after you ate the same food and it all started at once.

If you and someone else have the same symptoms but did not eat the same food lately, suspect the stomach flu.

Would you like to see our entry for food poisoning or Continue?

10.header: Do you also have a headache with all these?

11.header:
Alright.
See the entry for food poisoning or stomach flu if you are suspecting any of them.

Would you like to Continue or see the nearest urgent care clinic to you?

12.header:
Was this a nagging headache before the nausea / vomiting and diarrhea started?

Or after the nausea and vomiting?

13.header:
Before?
If it is before, probably looking at food poisoning.

Often times, food poisoning start with you feeling a nagging headache, then fever, feeling tired, before you start throwing up with diarrhea and the rest.

Would you like to see our entry on food poisoning or Continue to see other situations associated with nausea and or vomiting?

14.header:
After?
Suspect food poisoning if a nagging headache before the nausea and vomiting.

If it is after and you know someone else has the same symptoms and you did not eat the same food or you might have come in contact with some one with the stomach bug, then it is probably a stomach flu.

Would you like to see the entry for stomach flu or Continue to check out the other situations that involve nausea and or vomiting with fever?

20.header:
Are you feeling a sharp pain in your lower right or middle abdomen?

With this nausea, vomiting, fever?

21.header: Let's make sure you are not looking at appendicitis.

22.header:
Was this a dull aching pain that moved from your navel to the right lower part of you stomach?

And grew sharper with time?

23.header:
Yes?
This can be a sign of appendicitis.

Let's make sure you are not looking at one and if so do the right thing.

24.header:
Press on the area of the pain and release the pressure.

Does the pain get sharper?

26.header: Does the pain get worse when you cough or walk and you prefer to lie still?

27.header:
Go to the Emergency Room.

Here is why:

  • This is a sign of appendicitis.

Note:
You should only continue if you are not experiencing the question asked.

28.header:
Are you shaking with this pain, nausea and/or vomiting?

With chills?

29.header:
Go to the Emergency Room.

Here is why:

  • Possible signs of appendicitis.

Note:
You should only continue if you are not experiencing the question asked.

30.header:
Those were possible signs of appendicitis.

You should seek emergency room visit if most applied to you.

Know that if your appendix ruptures, you may feel less pain for a short time and even feel better.

But, the lining of the abdomen will get swollen and infected (peritonitis) and then the pain will get worse and you will become very sick.

If you don't think you are looking at appendicitis, let's continue and find out what else may be causing this nausea and vomiting.

40.header: With this nausea and fever do you also have upper right or middle abdominal pain?

41.header: Let's make sure you are not looking at gallstones attack.

42.header:
Is this like a dull, constant pain?

May also be sharp and cramping.

43.header:
Yes?
This is a sign of a gallstone attack going on.

44.header:
Does this pain spread to below the right shoulder blade?

Or your back?

45.header:
Yes?
This is a sign of gallstone attack.

You will need to seek emergency room visit or at a minimum urgent care if this apply to you. Would you like to do that or Continue?

46.header:
Is your skin turning yellow?

Or are you passing clay-colored stools?

47.header:
Seek urgent care or emergency room.

Here is why:

  • Sign of gallstone attack.

48.header:
Those were signs of a gallstone attack.

If this apply to you, seek emergency room visit. If not, let's see what else may be causing this nausea and or vomiting with fever.
